subsection.subsectiontext: The Homeowner Protection Office is established consisting of the board appointed under section 4 (1).
The purposes of the office are

paragraph.paragraphtext: to license residential builders and other persons required to be licensed under this Act,
to carry out research and education respecting residential construction in British Columbia, and
to administer the program.

subsection.subsectiontext: [Repealed 2007-20-2.]

Subject to the approval of the Lieutenant Governor in Council, the office, for the purpose of carrying out any power, right, function or duty conferred or imposed on it under this or any other Act, may borrow the sums of money it considers necessary or advisable.
The office is a corporation and has the power and capacity of a natural person of full capacity.
The office is, for all purposes, an agent of the government and its powers may be exercised only as an agent of the government.
The Public Service Act and the Public Service Labour Relations Act do not apply to the office or to a member, officer or employee of the office.
The Business Corporations Act does not apply to the office but the Lieutenant Governor in Council may order that one or more provisions of that Act apply.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council must

paragraph.paragraphtext: appoint as members of the board at least 3 persons who hold office during pleasure, and
designate one of the members as chair of the board.

subsection.subsectiontext: The board must manage the affairs of the office or supervise the management of those affairs.
The board must appoint a person as chief executive officer for the office and may determine the remuneration and the terms and conditions of the appointment.
The office may pay to a member

paragraph.paragraphtext: an allowance for reasonable travelling and incidental expenses necessarily incurred in carrying out the business of the office, and
if the member is not a member of the Legislative Assembly or a public servant, remuneration at rates set by the Lieutenant Governor in Council.

section.marginalnote: Powers and duties of the chief executive officer

subsection.subsectiontext: The chief executive officer must do all of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: designate the registrar and the director of research and education;

appoint officers, including compliance officers, and hire employees as the chief executive officer considers necessary, and set the terms and conditions of their employment, including their remuneration and duties;
advise the minister respecting home warranty insurance or any other matter under this Act;
perform other prescribed powers and duties.

subsection.subsectiontext: The chief executive officer may act as the registrar or the director of research and education, and may perform the duties of either of them.

The office must establish and maintain an accounting system satisfactory to the Minister of Finance and must, whenever required by that minister, render detailed accounts of its revenues and expenditures for the period or to the day that minister designates.
All books or records of account, documents and other financial records of the office must at all times be open for inspection by the minister or a person designated by the minister.
The Minister of Finance may direct the Comptroller General to examine and report to the Minister of Finance on any or all of the financial and accounting operations of the office.

Unless the Auditor General is appointed in accordance with the Auditor General Act as the auditor of the office, the office must appoint an auditor to audit the accounts of the office at least once each year.
The office must, within 90 days of the fiscal year end, submit annually to the minister, in a form approved by the minister,

paragraph.paragraphtext: a report of the office on its operations for the preceding fiscal year,
a financial statement showing the revenues, expenditures, assets and liabilities of the office as of the end of the preceding fiscal year, and
the annual report of the auditor of the office.

subsection.subsectiontext: The financial statement referred to in subsection (5) (b) must be prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
The financial statement and reports referred to in subsection (5) must be laid before the Legislative Assembly by the minister as soon as practicable.
The Minister of Finance is the fiscal agent of the office.

The Lieutenant Governor in Council may designate administrative services that the office must obtain from the government or from any government corporation, agency, branch or ministry or other government organization or entity that is specified in the order making the designation.
